petitioner.name: JOAN WAGNON, SECRETARY, KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF REVENUE

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will now hear argument in Wagnon vs. Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation. Mr. Olson.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, may I ask you to go one step beyond that on an issue of fact that I just don't understand from reading the briefs?  Let me give you three quick quotations. First, the court of appeals opinion contains this statement, "An expert on behalf of the tribe reported that basic economic theory teaches that the nation's station cannot charge prices high enough to allow collection of both the Kansas and the nation's fuel  taxes." The red brief says, on page 8, "It is undisputed that enforcing the State tax on fuel sold and delivered to the station would effectively nullify the tribal fuel tax." Finally, the yellow brief, on page 13, says, "By selling its fuel at market prices, respondent" -- the tribe -- "is making both a profit and collecting a tax." My question is, Do we know, from the record, whether the tax that is assessed on the distributor is, in fact, passed through to the tribe so that, in economic effect, the tribe is collecting, via pass-through, the State tax and imposing its own tax and still selling at market prices?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Make it up on volume, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But if -- if I may interrupt you -- if it's getting passed through, and they're still selling their gas, then there's no -- then the tribe cannot make an argument here that their sovereign taxing authority is being compromised or threatened.  And the argument, basically, would boil down to the argument that they want to make a bigger profit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or want to impose a higher tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or want to impose a higher tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but aren't they going to tell us that -- as a practical matter, that the tax is really being collected for the retailers?  It's just being passed on to the retailers, but paid by the -- I take it that the distributor -- the way this works -- I, again, had problems with effect -- I take it the distributor sends out a truck.  And if he sends out the truck to the tribe, then the distributor just pays the tax, and the tribe would want that tax to be -- that fuel to be distributed, less the cost of the tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And if the tribe view prevails, then the distributor still sends the truck to the stations that are in the State and passes on the tax for those --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- distributors only.  I take  it that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, what event triggers, if you will, the incidence of the tax on the distributor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is it -- is it the obligation -- is it the minute the fuel is brought into Kansas?  Is it when it is delivered to the distributor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Or is it later?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: So, the distributor gets the  fuel and incurs the obligation at that point, whether or not it's resold.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But doesn't incur it, or gets a credit or get it back, if it sells to the United States or if it sells out-of-State.  In other words, it's not just the receipt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And out-of-State or abroad --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then that's the problem, right there, because I thought -- first, there is a tax -- you get a credit if you don't sell the fuel to anybody.  So, I don't think it's quite -- if you just sit there with --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Maybe not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You don't?  All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You'd still have to pay tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, on --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You are Kansas.  You sell -- the retailer in Kansas sells it to Nebraska.  Nebraska is, in a sense, a foreign and independent State.  And I guess, at some level, the tribes are arguing, "Well, you sell to  us, our local retailer.  We, too, are a foreign and independent State, even more so.  So, if you're going to treat them this way -- give the people in Nebraska a credit so they don't have to pay -- why don't you treat us that way?  We drive on Kansas roads sometimes.  So do the Nebraskans" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- -- "sometimes."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, they say -- get into interest balancing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, what -- now you have the whole argument that I'm thinking of.  What do you respond?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But, Mr. Olson, would it make any difference if all of the driving was inside the reservation?  Would it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- make any difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, that -- that has been what's discussed in the brief, and I think that the court, in Chickasaw, was saying, If the State puts the incidence on the tribe itself, we don't have to look any further. That's what it said.  When the State levies a tax directly on the tribe or members inside the reservation, no balancing.  But then it also said that if the incidence rests on non-Indians, as here, with the distributor here, then there is no categorical bar, than balancing kicks in. So, all Chickasaw dealt with, with the categorical rule, is when the State says the incidence of the tax is on the  tribe.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Olson, the Solicitor General tells us that -- and here we have -- you have the statute, but they have the Kaul case that suggests that this tax is imposed on the reservation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but, again, that would still be true if the incidence -- the tax was on the retailer rather than the wholesaler.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which the statute contemplates will be collected when the gas is sold to the -- by the retailer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But what a strange provision. I mean, who would have thought that he couldn't?  Why did

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- they ever put that provision in, unless it means something different from --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, what does it mean when they say, in law, the "incidence of the taxes on the distributor"?  Does that mean anything other than that he has to pay it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I guess the reason  for my question is, they look back at the court's decisions and see that it turns on where the incidence of the tax is.  And so, there's some bright lawyer in Kansas who said, "All we have to do is pass a law saying the incidence is -- of the tax is on the distributor, and we're going to win."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, it suggests that we shouldn't give too much weight to that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: May I go back to one factual nuance on that?  Apart from legal incidence, somebody mentioned earlier that the tax would not necessarily be payable until, in fact, the gasoline was distributed to the retailer.  Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But isn't that a surrogate for sale to the -- well, I guess what I'm getting at, the tax apparently is not payable when the distributor receives the fuel, but only when the distributor transfers the fuel to a retailer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, why would he be drawing it down, except to sell --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, in terms of the text of the statute that is -- the incidence is on the distributor of the first receipt, but then there's this language -- and it appears in a few places -- "the tax is hereby imposed on the use, sale, or delivery."  What does -- what does that mean, that the tax is imposed on the use, sale, or delivery?"

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Does that mean, Mr. Olson, that the tax that the -- the fuel, rather, that's sold to the United States Government, later, out-of-State, when is the credit for the sales out-of-State made?  Is that made at the time of the initial delivery, or is -- do they ask for a refund a month later?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I couldn't tell from the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It seems to me that might be a way of identifying whether the term "legal incidence" really has any significance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I, sort of, take "legal incidence" to mean the duty to pay the tax.  And I'm just wondering whether -- when fuel is sold to a distributor that the -- I mean, the distributor knows the fuel is going to be resold to the United States -- does he have an exemption from the tax, because he knows what's going to happen to it, or does he have to pay the tax, or accept the obligation to pay the tax, and then --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- subtract, later on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Olson, you mentioned  Section 3410.  Where does that appear on --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I can't find it in anybody's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Olson --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I couldn't either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- could we go back --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask -- excuse me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- to the question that Justice Souter raised at the outset?  Because I'm really puzzled.  This is the picture I have of the case.  And please tell me where it's wrong. Two jurisdictions, both with authority to impose a tax, the State and the tribe.  So, if the other weren't taxing, there wouldn't be any question, that the tribe can tax and the State can tax.  But the two can't coexist, because the consumer's not going to pay the price.  So, only one can.  And the issue is, which one dominates, and which is one is subordinate?  But you have unquestionable authority to tax in both.  And I thought it was clear that  -- the two taxes did -- this is not a case where the tribe can impose a tax, the State can im- -- oppose.  I read the briefs to accept that the tribe tax -- couldn't put its tax on top of the State tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But not tax-free.  I mean, the -- a big thing that was made in this case was that, unlike the cigarette sales in the smoke shops, the tribe is not trying to market a tax exemption.  It is putting on its own tax, which will cost the customer, in the end, the same as if there had been a State tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who is it taxing?  Is it taxing itself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, the tribe sells the gas

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- doesn't it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Olson. Mr. Gershengorn.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is it collecting that tax?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then what's its gripe?  It wants a bigger profit?  It wants to increase --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the taxation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but if --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- if the tribe is collecting -- it's assuming that -- if the tribe is collecting its tax, and it does not have a claim to greater taxation or greater profit, then how is its sovereign right as a taxing authority being interfered with?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Loss of profit --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- as an entrepreneur.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, isn't -- I mean, isn't that necessarily the case?  If it's collecting all of its tax, then what it's complaining about is that it's getting less profit as the -- as the retailer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right.  Then is that an issue that we should consider on a question of preemption which arises from the tribe's assertion of sovereignty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, in other words --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- should we, in effect, say there is no distinction between the tribe's position as sovereign and the tribe's position as retail gasoline- seller.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, they're similar, because it -- ultimately, it's all going into the same pocket.  We  realize that.  But, unless there is a claim that its taxing authority, as such, is being threatened or interfered with, I don't quite see why a preemption theory that rests upon tribal sovereignty has any place in the analysis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But it's not operating at a loss.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's strange about it?  I mean, every upstream tax, as Mr. Olson said, raises the price of goods and services.  And it's harder to retail them, because they cost more.  So, that's true of every single good sold on the reservation.  So I take it your claim must -- and, of course, it may or may not be true  that the tribe can put a tax on that.  It depends upon

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But suppose they can't?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, my question is, If we hold for you here, and we don't take an absolute principle, well, I guess States are forbidden to put any upstream taxes on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why isn't that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, isn't it -- but they say no, that it's imposed on the delivery to the distributor --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- of fuel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, it's what the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- statute says.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's just a subsequent deduction.  I mean, if we get income, we're taxed on it.  If we make a charitable contribution, we get a deduction.  But that doesn't mean we don't have to pay and are subject to the income tax.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Where is --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- where is it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- works with the income tax, too.  You have casualty losses and things like that. It turns out you were subject to the tax, but you don't have to pay it, because you get a deduction.  But that doesn't mean you're not subject to it in the first place.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, we ought to know, because they've been -- haven't they had this for a while?  So, there must be a dealer somewhere who's not on the reservation -- he's a distributor -- somebody delivered to him a thousand gallons, and it's sitting there in his  -- -- tank.  Doe he have to pay the tax, or doesn't he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, if he would --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- pay the tax, then it is not

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- on his --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- redistribution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He is -- sorry -- if -- I'd like to ask the question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If -- and you can say why this is wrong -- if he gets a thousand gallons from whoever -- Exxon or somebody -- and he puts it in the tank, and he hasn't sold it, and he has to pay the tax, then it would seem to me to be a sale on the distribution to him, not the sale on his distribution to somebody else.  Now, why is that wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, now you're telling me something different from what I understood.  I thought you said it probably has happened in the history of this tax

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that a distributor picked up a gallon of fuel, held it, and has not yet redistributed it.  So, you're saying that's never happened.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If I'm certain about what the tax is on, what should we do?  Dismiss the case or send it to the -- ask a question, or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I think we can --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- I think we can decide it on the basis that we know that when the distributor puts -- delivers gas to the gas station, it's not instantly sold. I mean, even we know that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, the statute says

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- the statute says it's a tax on the sale, but then it goes on and says it's the first sale, and the first sale is to the distributor, and that's why the incidence of the tax is on him.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But nobody -- but it's not sold -- it's not taxed twice.  If it's sold to a distributor, that distributor has to pay the tax.  The distributor then sells it to someone else.  That someone else doesn't have to pay the tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if -- what -- perhaps the State expresses it that way just to cover some people who get their gas illegally, and they would say the tax is still due, even if you haven't gotten your gas from a distributor who has paid the State tax.  Wouldn't that suffice for why the court imposes the tax on the use, sale, or delivery?  Use, sale, or delivery.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, suppose you're right.  Can you answer my first question?  Can you even remember it?  I'll summarize.  On your assumption.  Look, the Indians, if there is a tax -- they have a retail shop or they have things on the reservation, they go buy them -- Kansas can't impose a tax on what goes on, on the reservation.  We go through the balance.  But they certainly could impose a tax on the department store in Kansas City, couldn't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And so, the Indian then goes to the department store and buys it.  He has to pay the tax, doesn't he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  Now what he does, he says, "Call up and" -- he says, "Please deliver it."  Now he doesn't have to pay the tax?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is the commerce constitutionally --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- we're now talking Federal rules.  Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it relevant --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you what the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- to the balancing test --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- may I ask you a question about the Federal exemption?  In your view, is that made available at the time of the initial purchase by the distributor, or does he have to, in effect, claim a credit later on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So that he -- his obligation to sell the gas is -- arises at the same time as his purchase.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And it shows both what they resell to the United States and what they acquired.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And let me ask you this question, too, on that subject.  Do you think that the exemption that the State allows for resales to the United States is constitutionally compelled?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And it's no under our --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- our precedent, I think, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It's no, under our precedent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, on that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- on the legal incidence of the tax, we suggested, in the Chickasaw Nation case, that a tax statute's own declaration of the legal incidence would be dispositive.  So, why don't we read the statute and say the incidence is on the distributor, and that's the end of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, I thought that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- what we suggested in Chickasaw Nation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Chickasaw said when the tax was imposed on the tribe, we would take the State at its word.  It said it's taxing the tribe.  If the State put the tax on a non-Indian, then there would be balancing. And that's what Chickasaw --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  So, if balancing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- then how do you come out? Because what they're saying is, "Okay, balance.  Fine. You want to balance?  Here's how you balance."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: On the one hand, the Indians have to pay the tax.  Okay, that's true.  And it's harder for them to impose their own tax.  That's true of every upstream tax.  And it goes for roads that they use all the time.  And they just have a one-and-a-half mile -- and why shouldn't they be treated every -- like everybody else, when they're going to use the roads the tax pays for?  So, the balancing works in their favor.  Now, what's your response?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why should all of that make a difference?  You make a big point in the briefing, "Well, you're not marketing the exemption, you're taxing, you're using" -- if the -- if the tribe does have the sovereign right to tax or not to tax, why can't it use it not to tax at all and say, "We're giving" -- why is there a presumption in favor of imposing taxes?  Why can't the tribe say, "We're not going to tax you if you come to the reservation.  Come on in and buy our gas.  No tax"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why isn't -- why isn't that part of the tribal sovereign right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who is -- who is the tribe taxing?  Is the tribe taxing the purchaser of the gas?  Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought the retailer was the tribe.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, it's taxing itself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's real neat.  I have never heard of that before. [Laughter.]

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, did I understand your earlier discussion, about the department store, to suggest that if the tribe had the tanker truck, and they picked up the fuel and then brought it back, that, in that case, you have no objection to the tax, even though the economic incidence and effect is going to be the same?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But is it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- constitutionally compelled to do so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Cities and counties --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But your --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- aren't sovereign.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- your claim wouldn't disappear if they decided to tax all these other sovereigns.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Your claim, as a tribe, would not disappear if they decided to become nondiscriminatory and tax all of the sales.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And your view generally was that it was -- that it was indicative of discrimination.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And I thought that was the stronger argument, because the -- you're saying, "Look, the State has only the most trivial interest in the amount of taxation it would get here."  That would be equally true whether it forgives taxes that -- on fuel that goes to the United States or not.  But the discrimination point, if it's a fair one, would be the same.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, it would matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All the other sovereigns you mentioned do not consume the gas -- or the gas sold to them is not consumed primarily on the roads of this State, except for cities and counties, which aren't sovereigns. I mean, they simply aren't sovereign.  That's the State, itself.  They're subdivisions of the State.  So, it's making exemptions for its own -- its own State, plus exemptions for sovereigns, where the gas sold to those sovereigns probably will not be used primarily on the roads of this State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It makes perfect sense.  I don't see there's any discrimination.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Kneedler.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is it being interfered with?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, that expert opinion is that, as an economic matter, you can't collect both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You can't impose both.  But the tribe is still imposing its tax, and it's getting every penny that it -- that it purports to impose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- in the record?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Let's assume -- let's assume that is true.  What difference does that make to an analysis based on a preemption theory which is supposed to  take account of tribal sovereignty?  The sovereign act is not selling gas, it's taxing.  They are taxing.  They're getting everything they want under their tax statute. Where, then, is there a basis for a preemption --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I mean, it was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- an entirely separate -- an entirely separate rationale.  It was saying the tribe is getting this tremendous advantage by -- or wants this tremendous advantage -- by marketing the exemption.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, maybe -- maybe it contemplated that, and maybe it simply contemplated that that particular -- that particular argument against it -- i.e., that it was simply selling a tax exemption -- would not have been an argument against it.  But it doesn't follow, from that, that the tribe would necessarily have had a winning argument on a preemption theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, if that's a winning -- of course it is different, in the sense you say, but if, in fact, it's an interference -- look, every upstream tax raises the price of goods and services.  Every upstream tax -- indeed, every tax in the world -- makes it harder to sell the product.  So, every tax makes it harder for the tribe to tax that item which was taxed by somebody else.  Now, if that's the basis for saying it's an interference, then every tax is an interference.  And I don't see how that could be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But, so far, your theory is  based on economics, as I've heard it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if it isn't, I would like to know what it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The incidence of the tax --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's very surprising.  When I read the statute, it doesn't have one word about the retailer being obliged to pay --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, if that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the legal incidence of the tax, I would think their side would win, in my mind.  Now suppose, actually, the legal incidence of the tax is not on that retailer, but, rather, is on the distributor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If that's so, and if we get into balancing, which I don't know, what is to be said in favor of the Indian side?  It sounded to me as if it's harder for them to tax.  So, I'm thinking, well, that's true of every tax.  And then, put it on something else. Put it on the tires.  Put it on anything else, if you can. It'll be harder for them to tax non-Indians.  But I didn't know they had a Federal right to tax the non-Indians.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, why isn't it the sale between whoever is selling it to the distributor and the distributor?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It would seem to me exempting distributor-to-distributor taxes just means that only one distributor has to pay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, but that's because there was a tax on the first sale to the first distributor.  And may I ask this?  Supposing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, but that's because when a distributor sells to another distributor, he is not acting, for purposes of that sale, as a distributor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If you sell to another distributor, you're not being --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But none of this -- none of this mattered to the tenth circuit, though, did it?  I mean, they didn't care where the incidence was.  They just went right into the balancing, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you think that was wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is the one other -- the interest other than the interest on being able to tax an  -- item that an upstream tax prevents you from doing because of the economics?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that the only one, or are there other ones?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I've got the -- --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- I want to hear you and know if there's an additional one.  I'm not disputing that one. I just want to be sure I get them all.  One is -- one is that one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I just don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- understand.  Why doesn't the tribe have an incidence of not having any tax at all, helping --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- helping its members?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why does the balancing only work if it taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, no, no.  You say that it could --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- market the exemption?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You say that a tribe can market its exemption?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, why isn't that sovereign interest in not taxing?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Kneedler. Mr. Olson, you have four and a half minutes left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about the Supreme Court's characterization of this as being --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I take it Kansas has not  indicted the distributor for failing to register under the Indian Trading Statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Aren't there usually two incidents?  You talk about the incident of the taxes on a person, but it's also on an event.  And what event is -- in your -- in your judgment is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But if the fuel --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- were destroyed by flood or lightning or something like -- before it was resold to the retailer, there would be no tax --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Are there any incidents in which the distributor would pay the tax if he was not able  to resell it to somebody else?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Olson.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
